dc:description: *GJA5* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant congenital heart disease in 2004 (Christiansen et al PMID 15117819) when 3 deletions were identified on chromosome 1q21.1 which included *GJA5* as well as several other genes. There have been multiple publications demonstrating deletions and duplications of 1q21.1 in patients with congenital heart disease (PMID 15117819, 19597493, 22318994, 22939634, 24021551, 26279651, 28905115, 35045913). A recurrent missense variant was identified in two patients with tetralogy of Fallot but the maximum allele frequency was above the allele frequency threshold of 1x10-5 so these variants were not scored. This gene disease relationship is supported by expression studies, a mouse model with congenital heart defects, protein interaction data,  (PMIDs 9285645, 12842919, 15537493). In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between *GJA5* and autosomal dominant congenital heart disease has been disputed due to the lack of human genetic evidence and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role GJA5 plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Heart Disease GCEP on the meeting date 4/2/2024 (SOP version 10)
curationReasonDescription: No human genetic evidence to support this association.

evidence.dc:description: Mice lacking one or both copies of Cx40 demonstrate structural congenital heart defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.dc:description:
Co-transfection experiments showed the ability of Nkx2-5 and GATA4 to transactivate the minimal Cx40 promoter while Tbx5 repressed Nkx2-5/GATA4-mediated activation.
 Mutagenesis of the Nkx2-5 core site in the Cx40 promoter led to significantly decreased activity in rat smooth muscle cell line A7r5. 
Consistent with this, mouse embryos lacking Nkx2-5 showed a marked decrease in Cx40 expression.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cotransfection experiments

evidence.dc:description:
At day 9.5 dpc, Cx40 is found in vascular endothelial cells as well as the atrial wall. 
Cx40 transcript was highly expressed in the vasculature and was observed in the paired dorsal aortas, the intersegmental arteries sprouting from the aortas, the brachial arch arteries, the primary head arteries and branching vessels, the atrium, and the common ventricular chamber 
During development, between 9.5 and 12.5 dpc, the vascular expression pattern of Cx40 transcript was modified after the rearrangement of the vasculature
At 9.5 dpc in situ hybridization experiments showed that Cx40 transcript was clearly detectable in the thin atrial wall. Immunofluorescence experiments carried out at the same stage demonstrated that the Cx40 protein was associated with the myocytes
From 10.5 dpc there is strong activation of the Cx40 gene in the left ventricle, which was expressed by an accumulation of transcript in this region and then was detected in the RV at 11.5 dpc. Later, it is expressed in myocytes of the developing conduction system
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse embryo expression

evidence.dc:description:
Cells expressing the mutant protein form sparse or no visible gap-junction plaques in the region of cell–cell contact. 
Analysis of the transfer of the gap junction permanent tracer lucifer yellow showed that cells expressing the mutant protein have a reduced rate of dye transfer
compared with wild-type cells. 
Zebrafish model revealed that microinjection of the mutant disrupts overall morphology of the heart tube in 37% of embryos compared to 6% of wild type.
Allele frequency in Gnomad 0.0003032, above threshold.
